abstract.t: This document describes the solution and design of application that extends multicast DNS services across links as realized in Cisco network router, switch, wireless LAN controller products.

note.title: Requirements Language

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Service discovery using multicast DNS (mDNS) as defined in is limited in scope to layer 3 boundaries due to the use of link-local scoped multicast addresses. <Due to partitioning of network into multiple virtual local area networks and subnets for various reasons there is a need to extend services using mDNS beyond L3 boundaries... TBD elaborate>
Enabling Service Discovery across L3 boundaries can be accomplished in two ways:

list.t: Defining mDNS gateway entity at the L3 boundary that will extend services
Modifying mDNS to use a wider scope multicast address

section.t: This draft lists out the approach to use mDNS gateway to extend the services. The mDNS gateway approach has following advantages:

list.t: Optimizes service discovery traffic across the network as against relying on site scope multicast. Using a wider scope multicast could lead to services being advertised and queried creating a deluge of service discovery traffic depending on number of hosts, services in the scope.
Yields to configuring and selectively extending specific/relevant services across the network
Extend service discovery across Layer 3 boundaries
Filtering services to be extended based on service type, service instances
Filtering of queries and announcements from specific clients
Optimize service discovery muticast traffic in wireless networks
Services that resolve to IPv4 and IPv6 Link Local addresses only must not be extended beyond local link.
Regardless of the topology, duplicate requests and responses must be avoided
A mechanism for automatically handling duplicate host names. Extended names and service offerings must follow mDNS specifications
A mechanism to protect system memory that maintains and extends services across links
A feedback michanism to inform client about serivce denail based on the policy configured on mDNS gateway.

section.title: Conventions and Terminology Used in this Document
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in "Key words for use in RFCs to Indicate Requirement Levels" [RFC2119].

This document uses the multicast DNS and DNS terminology and conventions from and . It uses the same convention for services on the same link as defined in [ID-cheshire-mdnsext-hybrid], repeated here for quick reference:
Multicast Multicast DNS works between a hosts on the same link. A set of hosts is considered to be "on the same link", if:
when any host A from that set sends a packet to any other host B in that set, using unicast, multicast, or broadcast, the entire link-layer packet payload arrives unmodified, and
a broadcast sent over that link by any host from that set of hosts can be received by every other host in that set

The link-layer *header* may be modified, such as in Token Ring Source Routing [802.5], but not the link-layer *payload*. In particular, if any device forwarding a packet modifies any part of the IP header or IP payload then the packet is no longer considered to be on the same link. This means that the packet may pass through devices such as repeaters, bridges, hubs or switches and still be considered to be on the same link for the purpose of this document, but not through a device such as an IP router that decrements the TTL or otherwise modifies the IP header.
mDNS gateway - An application that listens to services and extends the services across links
Service redistribution - unsolicited announcement of services across links
Active query - Service queries sent by the mDNS gateway on one or more of the links it is attached to

mDNS Gateway for Wireless Netowrk
section.t: Deployment of wireless netowrk is very different from that of wired network. One needs to conssider security, mobility and bandwidth aspects while implementing mDNS gateway solution for wireless netowrk.

section.title: Advertisng service on wireless network
section.t: Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) is changing the network architecture in almost every enterprise across verticals. In typical BYOD enabled Enterprice Network, different devices from the same user needs to be treated differently. In Service Provider WiFi (SP WiFi) deployemnts, multiple service providers would provide their service on the same SSID. Network need to become intelligent enough to provide services to the devices in a simplistic manner without compromising security. User based and device based service advertisements are primary requirements of BYOD and SP WiFi deployments.

If mDNS advertisements from distribution system (DS) are broadcasted on the SSID, then all the wireless clients would receive it and the service filters mention in [section: "Service Filters"] will not work. When wireless client sends a multicast mDNS query or report this will be unicated to Access Point (AP) so it does not need any change. Any mDNS multicast packet from DS to wireless devices should be converted to Layer2 Unicast (Layer 3 will still be multicat) and send to the eligible clients based on the service filters.

When a new service instance is learned by mDNS gateway, it sends the mDNS advertisement to the network so that all the network nodes gets updated. For wireless netowrk, mDNS gateway can act as passive device and respond only if wireless clients sends a mDNS query. This is very much necessory mainly for two reasons:

list.t: This will save computation resources on the device which are used to replicate the multicast packet as layer 2 unicast for all wireless clients.
If the wireless client is in power saving mode, sending mDNS advertisement as layer 2 unicast would forcefully awake the client and it would result in to more power consumtion by wireless clients.

section.t: mDNS functionality is not impacted by acting as passive gateway because client would always send mDNS query when it wants to avail any service.

section.title: Device Tracking
section.t: Wireless clients are very mobile in nature they can join and leave the netowrk any time. mDNS gateway should learn the service instance only from the authenticaed wireless client. mDNS gateway should tag each service instance from wireless client with the client's mac address. This mac address should be used for device tracking. If the wireless client leave the netowrk, gateway should not wait till TTL expiry but it should actively clean up the service instance provided by that wireless client.

If the device tarcking is not enabled, then any attacker can join the network and starts advertising with large TTL value and leave the network. By changing the mac address attacker can join the network again to polulate the service instances with large TTL value. This would fillup up the mDNS gateway cache with huge entries and it may lead to not learning to genuine services.

section.title: Mobility Considerations
section.t: Wireless deployments supports seemless mobility from one location to other location. In such scenario, mDNS gateway needs to be well aware of the client location and if the location changes, mDNS gateway needs to update its mDNS cache. mDNS gateway shuold tag each service instance with the device location. Device location can be derived based on the AP to which wireless client is attached. If the client who is providing any service changes its location, same needs to be reflected to mDNS gateway. If the client roams from one mDNS gateway to other mDNS gateway, then the old gateway should provide the service instance information pertaining to the roamed client to the new gateway and then it must clear the mDNS cache for the client. If the mDNS gateway is not acting as passive gateway, it may choose to update the network about the new service instance it has learned.

section.title: mDNS traffic optimization
section.t: All mDNS packets are sent to multicast link local ip address. When mDNS gateway starts forwarding the mDNS advertisements across VLAN then the number of such advertisement on any network would increase. 802.11 wireless netowrk is half duplex so any packet on air would need to contend for the wireless medium to transmit the packet. If there are many mDNS packets going on air then it would impact other data traffic. mDNS traffic optimization is very much need, when mDNS gateway solution is implemented for wireless network.

When services are advertised, different records comes with their owen TTL value. When TTL expires, gateway needs to send query (85%, 90% and 95% of TTL) for that record to confirm expiry of the record. If the TTL value of each record is different, then mDNS gateway needs to send query for individual record. If mDNS gateway update all the records with the same TTL, it cane send a single qury (layer 3 unicast) for the service instance for all the record during expiry. Client will also respond to the query with all the records in a singal response. This would minimize the mDNS traffic on air. Here the should be sent with QU bit set.

mDNS gateway can also send periodic mDNS generic query as layer 3 multicast (QU bit set) on air so that all the clients would respond to the query. This way mDNS gateway does not need to send unicast query to each client separately, as the cache would get updated provided query interval is less than TTL.

mDNS gateway for wireless network should act as passive gateway as explained in [section:Advertisng service on wireless network]. This would save some of the wireless bandwidth, as without passive gateway, it needs to unicast the mDNS advertisements to all the clients weather they are interested or not.

section.title: Feedback to inform client about Service Denial
section.t: Bonjour gateway applies filters to the services based on a user's context - identity, location, application and device in use. [Section "Service Filters"]. In certain situation, user would like to know the reason of denial. Like a guest user want to access a printer service which is denied for guest profile. In such cases, Bonjour gateway should be able to inform the denial message to client when the access is denied.

Since mDNS protocol does not support to send Denial message, Gateway can formulate the deny message as if it is a service instance. For example, if the service requested is "_ipp._tcp.local" then the deny message is formulated with the service instance string "Service Denied:[service name]._ipp._tcp.local". Here, [service name] would be user defined service name as configured on gateway or exact service string as appear in the query. mDNS gateway would send this service instance as mDNS query response with Layer2 destination of the querrier. The client who sent the mDNS query would receive this message as if it is a service advertisement. Client's mDNS software would then notify to the application about the service instance which is formulated by gateway to convey the service denial.. The additional information about the service denial should be carried by TXT record. The service name, a reason code, and a text string can be printed to the client service-listing screen for the user to see. In addition, contact information like Email, Phone number and URL pointing to certain web page can be included in the mDNS txt record for the user to obtain addition information for the denial. The user will be able to figure out the denial reason for his service request and recommended action.
